bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Harvey E. Jordan, October 21, 1940

div1.p: Hench offers to pay for a stenographer to record Moran's and Cooke's remarks if they speak at the University of Virginia dinner.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Harvey E. Jordan, October 21, 1940
div1.opener:
October 21, 1940
Dr. H. E. Jordan
University of Virginia
Deparymeny of Medicine
Charlottesville, Va.
My dear Dean Jordan:
div1.p:
I am so very sorry that Dr. Cooke is not going to
attend the Washington and Jefferson affair. I had so hoped
to meet him, particularly as I cannot go to Charlottesville.
I understand that Moran is visiting you next week and assume
that you are having a dinner and that Dr. Cooke may also
attend. In case you can persuade wither of these men to speak,
do you propose to have someone take down their remarks? I think
they will be of historical interest, particularly the remarks
of Dr. Cooke, who has for so long told so little of his own
experiences. I should be glad to pay part of the services of
a stenographer and also pay the cost of a carbon transcription
of their remarks. I think this may be very useful to me in
preparation for the full report which I hope to make on the
yellow fever experiments, but perhaps this suggestion is out
of place and if so, I know you will excuse it on the grounds
of my great interest in this story.
